messages.msgSnippet: DZ, I would like this. I hope others will share in kind. I am in the process of trying to improve my photography of tsuba, and would be willing to put up some
messages.messageBody:
DZ,

I would like this. I hope others will share in kind.
I am in the process of trying to improve my
photography of tsuba, and would be willing to put up
some of mine, along with relevant drawings, as a
'dissection' of them as I currently understand them.
But it would be best to do so with only NTHK or NBTHK
papered pieces. Afraid many of those I have at hand
currently are not papered. Still, willing to
try-though my questionable photography skills may
scuttle the effort.

Curran

I for one have enjoyed Jim's kantei(s). I am wondering if the other
members concur and if they might like something like a regular kantei,
possibly Friday with answer on Sunday? Or bi-weekly? Perhaps we could
generate a list of those interested in submitting their treasures with
one member being chosen by Jim each week. Then that party could post a
picture with Jim giving his ideas at the close of the bidding. That
way he'd be on the hot-seat as well (although I think luke warm in his
case at best LOL). Just some thoughts.

messages.msgSnippet: Jim and all Please bear in mind i am a novice at tsuba study, but this is so interesting i have to give it a shot......... The metal has a unique look , i
messages.messageBody:
Jim and all


Please bear in mind i am a novice at tsuba study, but this is so interesting
i have to give it a shot......... The metal has a unique "look", i have only
seen that in a few tsuba. The style and workmanship do give me the thought
of Hoan or Yagyu, but as another option the color and texture reminds me
of a Yamakichibei tsuba, so my guess is Yamakichibei. I look forward to
learning from the answer.

Mark Jones
nixe@...

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei
messages.msgSnippet: David and Richard have both given outstanding arguments supporting their judgments.  Any other opinions or arguments? Jim I should follow Rich s example, and
messages.messageBody:
David and Richard have both given outstanding arguments supporting their judgments. Any other opinions or arguments?

Jim




I should follow Rich's example, and explain my reasoning. The obvious choices are Kanayama & Owari. The melted iron surface, small size, & tekotsu in the rim all argue for Kanayama, and similar tsuba are often found just so classified. But Kanayama tsuba are more prone to difficult to identify motifs than Owari, and none of the characteristics here exclude Owari. So I thought it better to bet on the dark horse choice.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei
messages.msgSnippet: I should follow Rich s example, and explain my reasoning.  The obvious choices are Kanayama & Owari.  The melted iron surface, small size, & tekotsu in the rim
messages.messageBody:
I should follow Rich's example, and explain my reasoning. The obvious choices are Kanayama & Owari. The melted iron surface, small size, & tekotsu in the rim all argue for Kanayama, and similar tsuba are often found just so classified. But Kanayama tsuba are more prone to difficult to identify motifs than Owari, and none of the characteristics here exclude Owari. So I thought it better to bet on the dark horse choice.

----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, March 04, 2006 6:52 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei


We have two offline bids from people who saw the guard on exhibition in Tampa in addition to David and Richard's judgments. Anyone still working on a bid?

I won't give the setsumei tonight (EST) in any event.

Jim



OK, here is a guard for kantei:

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/2964?c

77.0 mm H x 74.8 mm W, 7.2 mm thick at the mimi and 7.1 mm thick at the seppa dai.


As far as I know it has not been published, but it has been exhibited at a couple of study meetings. So, if you've already seen it and remember the attribution, please don't post the answer to the list. It is mumei and there are two almost equally reasonable attributions, but I think that there is more evidence for one than the other.

Respond with your bid on or off list as you prefer.

Jim

messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, here is my attempt Interesting guard. There is an almost identical one in the Sasano Masterpiece book, under Owari. but the work on that guard is a
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim, here is my attempt

Interesting guard. There is an almost identical one in the Sasano
Masterpiece book, under Owari. but the work on that guard is a little
finer. Also, this kantei piece is quite thick for the average Owari work
but that won't preclude it for me. However, with the very strong
carving, it's thickness, tekkotsu and and elongated seppa dai, I will
for either go for Early Edo Kaneyama, or Late Muromachi/Momoyama Owari.
I am tempted to go for the Kaneyama kantei.

My bid is Early Edo Kaneyama.

Cheers

Rich Turner

messages.messageBody:
In regards supply of koudougu for kantei. There should be a large
supply of items published eg. in the Token Bijutsu, that if
permission obtained has all the leg work done and relatively good
opinions. This would also be a valuable resource, given a few years,
that could be archived and available to download for private
individuals. A conscious effort could be made to eventually include
examples from all schools. Right now it is memory work and
inconvenient to look through back issues. A thought.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba school
messages.msgSnippet: Hi John.  I agree on all points. Jim Hi Jim; I have studied the work of the Yoshiro and have never encountered a work in this style attributed to any of the
messages.messageBody:
Hi John. I agree on all points.

Jim



Hi Jim;

I have studied the work of the Yoshiro and have never encountered a work in this style attributed to any of the Yoshiro workers. The tsuba in question does not seem to me to have the age to the plate to justify such an attribution.

The metal in the plate, at least in the picture, shows no resemblance to any of the plates worked by the Yoshiro artists. Also the theme and design is not one that they were know to produce.

They were a very popular group in their day, their work was in high demand and available only to the wealthy. I find it difficult to believe that they would produce something so drastically different from what their bread and butter products were.

John

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei
messages.msgSnippet: It doesn t seem to be a standard practice, although I don t know why.  Usually kodogu is just displayed for study.  We did tsuba kantei a couple of times in
messages.messageBody:
It doesn't seem to be a standard practice, although I don't know why. Usually kodogu is just displayed for study. We did tsuba kantei a couple of times in the NY club. I made a small wooden clamp that would cover up the seppa dai but still allow the tsuba to be picked up. I haven't seen it done elsewhere. Doing kantei kai of mumei items is a little problematic since the "right" answer is still an opinion rather than a fact.

Doing it online has the handicap of not being able to see everything about the piece, but of course that's true too of paper kantei contests for swords. It could be done if someone has the time. It'd be easy enough to Photoshop out signatures.

Jim



Greeting's all. I guess this question may be directed to Jim more than
anyone else, but I am sure others will be more than keen to jump in if
they feel so inclined.

Are there ever any or many Tsuba or Tosogu Kantei ? I am sure there are
at group/club meetings and such but I was thinking more in line with the
Nihonto Kantei the NTHK offer in their monthly or Kenji Mishina offers
on-line.

The recent post's in regards to David and Curran's guards, with the
answers that ensued, got me thinking it would be great to see maybe 1/2
a dozen tsuba offered up each month for kantei. I guess the usual
aspects of kantei would remain the same, i.e. style, type of work, size,
thickness, tekkotsu if there and either an image with the mei ( if
applicable ) hidden or some sort.

Just a thought, sounds like fun to me :-)

any thought's on this ?

Cheers

Rich.

messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim;

I have studied the work of the Yoshiro and have never encountered a work in this style attributed to any of the Yoshiro workers. The tsuba in question does not seem to me to have the age to the plate to justify such an attribution.

The metal in the plate, at least in the picture, shows no resemblance to any of the plates worked by the Yoshiro artists. Also the theme and design is not one that they were know to produce.

They were a very popular group in their day, their work was in high demand and available only to the wealthy. I find it difficult to believe that they would produce something so drastically different from what their bread and butter products were.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, February 27, 2006 7:34 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba school


That is a strange call indeed. Nunome zogan and relief carving are not Yoshiro traits. If anyone has seen a signed Yoshiro example with either I'd like to hear about it.

Jim


There are certainly some unexpected Yoshiro papered attributions out there, aren't there?

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba school
messages.msgSnippet: David, It s sahari as Arnold and Rich have said.  It s not Hazama school sahari work though, which is the flush style of inlay that Arnold mentioned.  I ve
messages.messageBody:
David,
It's sahari as Arnold and Rich have said. It's not Hazama school sahari work though, which is the flush style of inlay that Arnold mentioned. I've seen several pieces of exactly this type, but no signed ones. The plates look like later Myochin work. On the ones I've seen in person the sahari appeared contemporary with the plate. It's possible that the sahari could be a later addition, but it's hardly something done to appeal to western taste.

I don't think that the overlapping squares add up to a genji mon.

Jim



Tom,


I'm probably misusing the term shakudo. Perhaps it's "melted-on something-or-other zogan." The tsuba is definitely old. I do own a nice collection of Tokyo Planning Office beer coasters and paperweights, all made last week.

David
http://zincavage.org/BrownTsuba.html




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba school
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, Do you have an alternative interpretation to Genji mon? My impression is that the goal of applying the melted sahari to the surface is to produce the
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

Do you have an alternative interpretation to Genji mon?

My impression is that the goal of applying the melted sahari to the surface is to produce the appearance of the bottom of a tidal pool or puddle. Would you agree with that?

This tsuba is very difficult to photograph. Its surface is very high relief, and the sahari is reflective. The seller's photos are better than any I've been able to make. It looks a bit better in person. It's "mud puddle" surface manages to convey simultaneously a sense of rustic wabe sabe simplicity and a sense that this is a really expensive luxury object which took an awful lot of trouble and skill to produce. Rusticity as sold at Tiffany's, if you see what I mean.

David

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba school
messages.msgSnippet: I am new to the group and am enjoying reading about the nuances of tsuba connoiseurship and collecting.  As an art conservator (though generally art on paper,
messages.messageBody:
I am new to the group and am enjoying reading about the nuances of tsuba connoiseurship and
collecting. As an art conservator (though generally art on paper, not metals) I'm able to give a
little bit of professional info on this one.
In the museum world, the general method for labeling objects is to first put down a coat, acting
as a barrier layer, of some sort of clear polymer. Nowadays it is usually a non-yellowing product
called paraloid B-72 which is soluble in toluene and/or xylene. Sometimes, clear nail polish is
used which is soluble in acetone. The ID# is then painted on this, and a second coat of the
polymer is used to make everything stay put.
I suppose some private collectors wouldn't hesitate to just use something like white-out or
liquid-paper for numbering. This will chip off easily. In instances where things are more
difficult, and you risk scratching the delicate metal surface, try a q-tip swab with a little of
the above mentioned solvents and it should do the trick.

Regards,
Doug Sanders
